text: Cell activation and apoptosis by bacterial lipoproteins through <extra_id_0> toll-like receptor-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
Apoptosis is implicated in the generation and resolution of inflammation in response to bacterial pathogens .
All bacterial pathogens produce lipoproteins ( BLPs ) , which trigger the innate immune response .

BLPs were found to induce apoptosis in THP-1 monocytic cells through <extra_id_0> human Toll-like receptor-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> hTLR2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) .
BLPs also initiated apoptosis in an epithelial cell line transfected with <extra_id_0> hTLR2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

text: In addition , BLPs stimulated nuclear factor-kappaB , a transcriptional activator of multiple host defense genes , and activated the respiratory burst through <extra_id_0> hTLR2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
Thus , <extra_id_0> hTLR2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is a molecular link between microbial products , apoptosis , and host defense mechanisms .
